newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech police charge 25 with bank credit fraud.
newsitem.headline: Czech police charge 25 with bank credit fraud.

text.p: A total of 25 people were charged on Wednesday with attempting to defraud 10 Czech banks between 1992 to 1994 of millions of crowns in unsecured loans, the interior ministry said.
Ministry spokesman Jan Subert said in a statement that a coordinated police operation throughout the country resulted in the arrests early on Tuesday.
The suspects were all transported to Prague where they were officially charged on Wednesday with committing "fraud resulting in major damages".
Subert said that those charged received "through fraudulent means, large unsecured loans from 10 Czech banking institutions".
He declined to list the banks, but said the credits ranged from five million crowns to 450 million czech crowns ($16.5 million), and total damages were in the "hundreds of millions of crowns".
Subert declined to offer further details on how the frauds were carried out.
"Among those charged are, other than businessmen, former professional soldiers, former policemen, and former officers of the (prison authority)," the statement said.
The largest number of those arrested were from the northern Czech cities of Liberec, Jablonec and Nisou.
The spokesman said the arrests resulted from a more than year-long investigation by detectives of the Division for Investigation of Organised Crime (UOOZ).
